title: How to Make Marbled Quail's Eggs

steps.headline: Place the quail's eggs in a saucepan of cold water and bring to the boil.
steps.description: Time them for 2 minutes from the moment when the water comes to the boil.

steps.headline: Transfer the eggs from the pan to a colander and run them under cold water to cool.
steps.description: Tap the shells all over so they are crazed, but do not peel the eggs.

steps.headline: In a large saucepan, bring the tea to the boil, then add the soy sauce,  sherry and star anise.
steps.description: Add the eggs and boil again for about 15 minutes, partially covered, so the liquid does not boil dry.

steps.headline: Remove the eggs from the pan.
steps.description: When they are cool, peel and arrange on a small platter lined with curly endive.

steps.headline: Mix the ground Szechuan peppercorns with an equal quantity of of salt and place the mixture in a small dish to serve with the eggs.

text: Place the quail's eggs in a saucepan of cold water and bring to the boil. Time them for 2 minutes from the moment when the water comes to the boil. Transfer the eggs from the pan to a colander and run them under cold water to cool. Tap the shells all over so they are crazed, but do not peel the eggs. In a large saucepan, bring the tea to the boil, then add the soy sauce,  sherry and star anise. Add the eggs and boil again for about 15 minutes, partially covered, so the liquid does not boil dry. Remove the eggs from the pan. When they are cool, peel and arrange on a small platter lined with curly endive. Mix the ground Szechuan peppercorns with an equal quantity of of salt and place the mixture in a small dish to serve with the eggs.
